item.title: Opinion Dynamics (REU Project)
item.description: I participated in the UCLA Computational and Applied Mathematics REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates), funded by the NSF, this summer. I collaborate with a team of 4 to conduct research, design 10+ experiments, build PDE solver with numerical analysis, optimize code, and create visualizations. We simulate Opinions Dynamics in a mathematical network with an adaptive Deffuant‚ÄìWeisbuch model in Python. Here is our final presentation. We are hoping to present our project at JMM 2024 and publish our paper early 2024.

item.title: Text Summarization
item.description: I worked with a team of 8 and implemented extractive text summarization with TF-IDF from scratch and with sklearn. Feel free to check out our GitHub, Streamlit demo, and Medium article.

item.title: Network Analysis with Social Media (Weibo)
item.description: I worked with Professor Mason Porter from UCLA’s Math Department on social network analysis, where I modeled a network to examine online community sentiment and behaviors (45k+ posts) under COVID lockdown. After extracting posts through requests and API, I conducted EDA and modeled the network using NetworkX. To examine users’ sentiments, I developed a deep learning sentiment analysis model for Mandarin Chinese text and achieved an 80+% accuracy. Check out my research proposal here or take a peek at my code base here.

item.title: Superlinearity of Protests
item.description: I’m working with Professor Steinert-Threlkeld from UCLA’s Public Affairs department to analyze if a superlinearity exists between city population and protest sizes. We are using ACLED dataset for protests across the world and Geonames for population. So far, no correlation has been found between the 2 variables. Feel free to check out the GitHub repo.

item.title: Time Series Forcasting for Oil Prices
item.description: In this project, I explored Oil Prices for the past 6 years (source) utilizing ARIMA and an state-of-the-art time series linear model. Check out my presentation here for to see the results. My ARIMA model achieved an MSE of 5.88 and < 0.01 for LSTF. Here’s the code for ARIMA models: GitHub repo.

item.title: üõ† How to Use Shortcodes?
item.description: What is a shortcode? It’s basically a block-level html code; you can write shortcodes yourself and find ones online that others have written for you. You have two sets of curly braces and a set of angle brackets { { < short code > } }. (For some reason the website won’t compile if I actually type it out correctly, which is without the spaces between each symbols.) Some shortcodes have opening and closing tags like html and some do not.

item.title: About
item.description: Hey, welcome to my website! My name is Emily Gong, a third year studying Math of Computation and Linguistics at UCLA. I’m passionate about data science, machine learning, and project/product management. You can find me on GitHub, LinkedIn, or through Email.

item.title: üéß How to Fetch Data through the Spotify API
üí° How to Make a Hugo Website
item.description: Why building a website with Hugo? In short, it’s a really fast and simple way to have a static website to yourself, through which you can display your recent projects, share your thoughts, and have fun with it. Before we officially start… The tutorial is based on macOS and I’m using GitHub Pages for deployment. Tools you’ll need Terminal A text editor like VSCode A GitHub account hugo Setting up Open your terminal - easy!

item.title: Exploring K-pop and BTS Song Popularity with Spotify Audio Features & Song Lyrics
item.description: In this group project I led, we tried to predict K-Pop song‚Äôs popularity through machine learning and natural language processing. We were first inspired by the BTS 147 Songs Audio Features (Spotify) dataset from Kaggle, but to conduct our analysis, we referred to the following two datasets: the Kpop Artists and Full Spotify Discography and BTS Lyrics dataset (more details in later sections). Before proceeding, we extracted the ‚ÄúPopularity‚Äù scores Spotify generated for each song we observed through the Spotify API and appended it to the datasets mentioned above.

item.title: Hello World!
item.description: This is my first time building a website and I’m hoping to add more fun stuff to it, like my data science projects, some design projects, and maybe some drawing + photography? We will see ;)
